'''SS ''Calabria''''' was a passenger and cargo steamship. [[AG Weser]] built her for [[Norddeutscher Lloyd]]. She was launched as '''D/S ''Werra''''' and completed in 1922. ("D/S" stands for ''Dampfschiff'' in German as "SS" stands for "steamship" in English.)
In 1935 she was bought by [[Italian Line|Flotte Riunite Cosulich-Lloyd-Sabaudo Navigazione Generale]], who renamed her '''''Calabria'''''. In 1937 she was sold to [[Italia Marittima|Lloyd Triestino]].
In June 1940 the UK seized her and placed in the management of the [[British-India Steam Navigation Company]]. In December 1940 she was torpedoed and sunk. When she sank, all of her 360 passengers and crew lost their lives. The [[Ministry of War Transport]] (MoWT) was going to rename her '''''Empire Inventor''''', but she was sunk before this had been done.
==Building and career== The [[Allies of World War I|Allied Powers]] seized numerous NDL ships either during the First World War as [[Prize (law)|prize ships]] or afterwards for [[World War I reparations|war reparations]]. In the 1920s NDL replaced them with a new fleet from [[Bremer Vulkan]], [[AG Vulcan Stettin]] and AG Weser. The first of the new ships were delivered in 1922; ''Werra'' among them.
''Werra'' was one of a series of six [[sister ship]]s that AG Weser built for NDL. ''Werra'' and {{SS|Weser|1922|2}} were completed in 1922;<ref name=LR33/> {{SS|Coblenz|1923|2}}, {{SS|Saarbrücken|1923|2}} and {{SS|Trier|1923|2}} in 1923<ref name=LR-Sicilia>{{cite book |url= http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=37b0800.pdf |year=1937 |title=Lloyd's Register, Steamers and Motorships |location=London |publisher=[[Lloyd's Register]] |accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref><ref name=LR-Toscana>{{cite book |url= http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=37b0886.pdf |year=1937 |title=Lloyd's Register, Steamers and Motorships |location=London |publisher=[[Lloyd's Register]] |accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url= http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=30b1219.pdf |year=1930 |title=Lloyd's Register, Steamers and Motor Ships |location=London |publisher=[[Lloyd's Register]] |accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref> and {{SS|Fulda|1924|2}} in 1924.<ref>{{cite book |url= http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=30b0438.pdf |year=1930 |title=Lloyd's Register, Steamers and Motor Ships |location=London |publisher=[[Lloyd's Register]] |accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref>
''Werra'' had two three-cylinder [[Marine steam engine#Triple or multiple expansion|triple-expansion steam engines]] and twin [[Propeller (marine)|screws]].<ref name=LR33/> Between them her two engines were rated at 604 [[Horsepower#Nominal horsepower|NHP]].<ref name=LR33/> ''Werra'' was equipped with wireless [[direction finding]] and submarine signalling.<ref name=LR33/>
In 1935 NDL sold ''Werra'', ''Coblenz'' and ''Saarbrücken'' to Flotte Riunite Cosulich-Lloyd-Sabaudo which renamed them ''Calabria'', ''Sicilia'' and ''Toscana'' and registered them in [[Port of Genoa|Genoa]].<ref name=LR36/><ref name=LR-Sicilia/><ref name=LR-Toscana/> In 1937 the three ships were sold to [[Italia Marittima|Lloyd Triestino]],<ref name=LR-Sicilia/><ref name=LR-Toscana/> which registered ''Calabria'' in [[Port of Trieste|Trieste]].<ref name=LR37/>
On 10 June 1940 Italy declared war on France and the United Kingdom. At the time ''Calabria'' was in drydock in [[Port of Kolkata|Calcutta]] in [[British Raj|British India]], so on 11 June the British authorities seized her.<ref name=Uboat/> She was transferred to the MoWT, which appointed the [[British-India Steam Navigation Company]] to manage her.<ref name=Uboat/> The MoWT planned to rename her ''[[Empire ship|Empire]] Inventor'', but this intention was overtaken by events.<ref name=Uboat/>
==Sinking== {{location map |North Atlantic |width=304 |lat=52.43 |long=-18.07 |caption=Approximate position of ''Calabria''{{'}}s wreck in the [[Western Approaches]] |relief=yes}} In December 1940 ''Calabria'' was ''en route'' to the UK with a cargo of 4,000 tons of iron, 3,050 tons of tea and 1,870 tons of [[oilcake]]. Her [[Sea captain|Master]], David Lonie, commanded 128 officers and crew plus one [[Defensively Equipped Merchant Ships|DEMS]] gunner.<ref name=Uboat/> She was also carrying 230 mostly Indian supernumaries who were travelling to crew other ships.<ref name=Uboat/> Calabria{{'}}s crew and supernumaries included also four [[Hong Kong people|Hong Kong Chinese]] crewmen<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.roll-of-honour.org.uk/Cemeteries/Hong_Kong_Memorial/html/a.htm |last=Taylor |first=Ron |title=Hong Kong Memorial Roll of Honour – A |work=Roll of Honour Britain at War |accessdate=30 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.roll-of-honour.org.uk/Cemeteries/Hong_Kong_Memorial/html/l.htm |last=Taylor |first=Ron |title=Hong Kong Memorial Roll of Honour – L |work=Roll of Honour Britain at War |accessdate=30 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.roll-of-honour.org.uk/Cemeteries/Hong_Kong_Memorial/html/t.htm |last=Taylor |first=Ron |title=Hong Kong Memorial Roll of Honour – T |work=Roll of Honour Britain at War |accessdate=30 June 2013}}</ref><ref name=Crew>{{cite web |url= http://uboat.net/allies/merchants/crews/ship710.html |title=Calabria |work=Crew lists from ships hit by U-boats |last=Helgason |first=Guðmundur |date=1995–2013 |publisher=Guðmundur Helgason |accessdate=30 June 2013}}</ref> and one Danish merchant officer.<ref name=Crew/>
''Calabria'' left [[Freetown]] in [[Sierra Leone]] with convoy [[List of World War II convoy codes#S|SLS]]-56 to the UK but fell behind.<ref name=Uboat/> On the evening of Sunday 8 December [[German Type IX submarine]] {{GS|U-103|1940|2}}, commanded by the [[Submarine aces|U-boat ace]] [[Viktor Schütze]], torpedoed her in the [[Western Approaches]] about {{convert|295|nmi|km}} west of [[Slyne Head lighthouse|Slyne Head]] in [[County Galway]], Ireland.<ref name=Uboat/> U-103 hit ''Calabria'' with one torpedo at 2058 hrs and a second at 2106 hrs.<ref name=Uboat/> All 360 hands and passengers were lost: there were no survivors.<ref name=Uboat/>
''Calabria''{{'}}s [[latitude]] was 52 degrees 26 minutes north, at that time of year the sun would have set just before 1600 hours local time, and the ship would have been [[Blackout (wartime)#World War II|blacked out]] under wartime regulations. However, [[Phases of the moon#Names of lunar phases|the moon was waxing gibbous]], had risen at 1315 hrs and did not set until 0218 hrs in the small hours of the next morning.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://aa.usno.navy.mil/cgi-bin/aa_pap.pl |author=US Naval Observatory Astronomical Applications Department |title=Sun and Moon Data for One Day |publisher=[[United States Navy]] |accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref> If the sky was clear, Schütze would have been able to target ''Calabria'' by moonlight.
The oldest man aboard was ''Calabria''{{'}}s chief cook, Santan Martins, who was 79 years old.<ref name=Crew/> Martins may have been the oldest merchant seaman killed at sea in the Second World War.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://ww2talk.com/forums/topic/15879-merchant-marine-deaths-ww2-the-oldest/ |author=Geoff501 |title=Merchant Marine Deaths WW2 - The Oldest? |publisher=WW2Talk |date=29 June 2009 |accessdate=30 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.militarian.com/threads/merchant-marine-deaths-ww2-the-oldest.5355/ |last=McGee |first=Billy |title=Merchant Marine Deaths WW2 - The Oldest? |publisher=Militarian Military History Forum |date=30 June 2009 |accessdate=30 June 2013}}</ref>
==Monuments and relics== Those who died in ''Calabria''{{'}}s sinking are commemorated in the Second World War section of the [[Tower Hill Memorial|Merchant Navy War Memorial at Tower Hill]] in London.<ref name=ConvoyWeb>{{cite web |url= http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/sl/mem/56_1.htm |last=McGee |first=Billy |title=MV Calabria (sic) |work=Convoy Web |accessdate=30 June 2013}}</ref> Her Indian seamen and supernumaries are commemorated in the [[Commonwealth War Graves Commission]] monuments at [[Chittagong]] and [[Mumbai]].<ref name=ConvoyWeb/>
In 1940 after the British seized ''Calabria'' a small bronze [[ship's bell]] was removed from her.<ref name=Bonhams>{{cite web |url= http://www.bonhams.com/auctions/20765/lot/11/ |title=11 A Bronze ship's bell, SS Calabria 1922 |publisher=[[Bonhams]] |date=24 April 2013 |accessdate=30 June 2013}}</ref> It was offered at auction in September 2012<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.bonhams.com/auctions/19925/lot/53A/ |title=11 A Bronze ship's bell, SS Calabria 1922 |publisher=[[Bonhams]] |date=26 September 2012 |accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref> and again in April 2013.<ref name=Bonhams/>
